George Leland Bach

Explanation:
George Leland Bach was hired by the Carnegie Institute of Technology in 1946 to restart the school's economics department. He had previously been working at the Federal Reserve during World War II. He added William W. Cooper from the field of Operations Research (which had increased its visibility during the war) and Herbert A. Simon, a political scientist who was to direct the undergraduate business program. The beginnings of the Cold War were applying pressure on the academic community to increase US managerial ability, and when William Larimer Mellon gave a $6 million grant to found a school of industrial administration, Bach became the first dean, bringing along the entire economics department. Under Bach's leadership, in 1958, the school's Management Game was the first to use computer simulations for experiential learning of business roles; such simulations have subsequently been adopted by other institutions. In 1989, the school's Financial Analysis and Security Trading Center (FAST) was the first educational institution to successfully replicate the live international data feeds and sophisticated software of Wall Street trading firms. Prior to the founding of the Tepper School, management education typically used the case method approach popularized at the Harvard Business School, based upon examples from successful companies and microeconomic theory. Joan Gabel is the 18th chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh. She was appointed to the position in 2022, following the retirement of Patrick Gallagher. Gabel is the first woman to hold the position of chancellor at Pitt. Prior to her appointment, Gabel served as the president of the University of Minnesota. She has a Ph.D. in political science and a law degree from the University of Michigan. Gabel has been a professor of law and political science at the University of Minnesota, and has also served as the dean of the University of Minnesota Law School. She has been a member of the American Bar Association and the American Political Science Association. Gabel is known for her work in the areas of constitutional law and public policy. She has written extensively on the subjects of voting rights, campaign finance, and the separation of powers. Gabel has also been involved in a number of legal cases, including the landmark case of Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission. Steel City (1859–1946)

The iron and steel industry developed rapidly after 1830 and became one of the dominant factors in industrial America by the 1860s. Scots Irish leadership

Ingham (1978) examined the leadership of the industry in its most important center, Pittsburgh, as well as smaller cities. He concludes that the leadership of the iron and steel industry nationwide was "largely Scotch Irish". Ingham finds that the Scotch Irish held together cohesively throughout the 19th century and "developed their own sense of uniqueness. " [ 36 ] New immigrants after 1800 made Pittsburgh a major Scotch-Irish stronghold. For example, Thomas Mellon (b. Ulster 1813–1908) left northern Ireland in 1823 for the United States. He founded the powerful Mellon family, which played a central role in banking and industries such as aluminum and oil. As Barnhisel (2005) finds, industrialists such as James Laughlin (b. Explanation:
The Monongahela River is crossed by the Expressway Bridge on the approach to Pittsburgh. The Expressway Bridge is a major highway bridge that carries Interstate 376 across the Monongahela River in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The bridge is located near the southern end of the city, just north of the Fort Pitt Tunnel and Fort Pitt Bridge. The Expressway Bridge is a key component of the Pittsburgh area's transportation network, providing a vital link between the city and the surrounding suburbs. The bridge is also an important landmark in the city, providing a scenic view of the downtown skyline and the surrounding hills. The Expressway Bridge is a double-decked structure, with the lower deck carrying traffic in both directions and the upper deck carrying traffic in one direction. The bridge is approximately 2, 000 feet (610 m) long and has a total of 12 lanes. The bridge was built in 1965 and has been the subject of several renovations over the years. 141:
PNC Park is the official home ballpark of the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Explanation:
PNC Park is the official home ballpark of the Pittsburgh Pirates. PNC Park is a baseball park located on the North Shore of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. It is the home of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the city's Major League Baseball franchise. Opened in 2001, the park is named after PNC Bank, which paid $ 68 million for the rights to name the stadium. The stadium was built as a replacement for Three Rivers Stadium, which had been the Pirates' home since 1970 and the home of the Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League since 1961. The stadium has a capacity of 38,747. It was the first stadium in the United States to be built with a retractable roof over a natural grass playing surface. The stadium is located along the Allegheny River, directly across from downtown Pittsburgh. It is served by the North Shore Connector, a light rail system that opened in 2012. The stadium has been praised for its views of the Pittsburgh skyline, its proximity to downtown, and its natural grass playing surface. 145:
Point State Park is a National Historic Landmark park that sits at the tip of Pittsburgh’s “Golden Triangle. ”

Explanation:
Point State Park is a National Historic Landmark park that sits at the tip of Pittsburgh’s “Golden Triangle. ” The park is located at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers, which form the Ohio River. The park is known for its scenic views of the city and its historical significance. It was the site of Fort Duquesne, a French fort built in 1754, and later became the site of Fort Pitt, a British fort built in 1761. The park is also home to several monuments and memorials, including the Liberty Bell and the Robert E. Lee statue.

The Three Rivers Heritage Trail is a 33-mile urban trail system that follows the three rivers of Pittsburgh and Allegheny County. It is a popular destination for hikers, bikers, and joggers, and offers stunning views of the city skyline and the surrounding countryside.

The trail system consists of a network of paved paths, boardwalks, and bridges that wind through the city and its surrounding suburbs. It passes through parks, along riverbanks, and through urban neighborhoods, providing access to a variety of attractions and amenities.

149: The Andy Warhol Museum is located on the North Shore of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, in the United States. It is the largest museum in North America dedicated to a single artist. The museum holds an extensive permanent collection of art and archives from the Pittsburgh-born pop art icon Andy Warhol. The Andy Warhol Museum is one of the four Carnegie Museums of Pittsburgh and is a collaborative project of the Carnegie Institute, the Dia Art Foundation and The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts (AWFVA). The museum is located in an 88,000-square-foot (8,200 m2) facility on seven floors. Containing 17 galleries, the museum features 900 paintings, close to 2,000 works on paper, over 1,000 published unique prints, 77 sculptures, 4,000 photographs, and over 4,350 Warhol films and videotaped works. Its most recent operating budget (2010) was $6.1 million. In addition to its Pittsburgh location the museum has sponsored 56 traveling exhibits that have attracted close to nine million visitors in 153 venues worldwide since 1996.
